title: DRC reports with poor/bad coordinates (lp:#1619133)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1619133) created by **PCB Wiz (1-pcb-wiz)**
```
DRC on the design give this report

ErrType(23): Copper areas intersect or are too close
    @ (45.155 mm,-7.899 mm): Zone Outline  (00000000) [+5V] on In2.Cu
    @ (45.155 mm,-7.899 mm): Zone Outline  (00000000) [+12V] on In2.Cu
ErrType(23): Copper areas intersect or are too close
    @ (45.155 mm,-7.899 mm): Zone Outline  (00000000) [+5V] on In2.Cu
    @ (45.155 mm,-7.899 mm): Zone Outline  (00000000) [+12V] on In2.Cu


That is of course useless to identify actual issue, as missing is the
ACTUAL distance (which DRC must know, so please tell the user !), and it
has duplicated one vertex, so the user cannot even derive the clearance
distance.

The actual design file has
(net_name +12V) (xy 45.155104 -7.8994)
(net_name +5V)  (xy 45.002704 -7.8994)

so the +5V line is using the WRONG vertex information.

That _info_ does show (see other post around missing markers), on mouse
query,  so I think it is a simple Cut & paste typo bug, in the report
generator.
```

title: Single layer view (lp:#1616153)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1616153) created by **Art (diametrix)**
```
The following feature, if implemented, would tremendously speed
  up board layout.

  - Single layer view - very useful to be able to be able to see just
  one layer.  High contrast mode is good but in a complex layout with
  multiple layers it is still essential.  Right now to see a single
  layer I need first move mouse to the layer tab deselect all other
  layers (can be a lot of clicking depending on the number of layers)
  then click on the render tab and deselect footprints on the opposite
  layer.  Now to switch to another layer again you have to do all that
  clicking again.  Need a single keyboard shortcut for that.

title: "Single pad nets delete" option of Read netlist is unnecessary (lp:#1615755)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1615755) created by **Novak Tamas (novak-7)**
```
I can't see the reason for "Single pad nets delete" option of Read netlist.

Eeschema always includes single pad nets (unconnected pins, even if they
are flagged not-connected in schematic) in netlist.
If this netlist is read into pcbnew, these single-pin nets will be loaded.
When Reading netlist next time, nothing happens if Single pad nets option
is set to Keep.
On the other hand, if this option is set to Delete, every run of Read
netlist
generates pairs of

Changing component "D2:/54AFB4C9" pin "3" net name from "" to
"Net-(D2-Pad3)".
Remove single pad net "Net-(D2-Pad3)" on "D2" pad '3'

messages for each of unconnected pins.

If you don't want to be flood by messages and filter out Infos and
Warnings, these messages keep displaying as they are type of Action.
Actions and Errors disabled is really bad idea.

My wish is opting out "Single pad nets delete" option from Read netlist (it
should always work like set to "Keep"). Rather may have an option in
eeschema Generate netlist, "Eliminate single pad nets from netlist"
```

title: Warn when reading out-of-date netlist (lp:#1610529)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1610529) created by **Novak Tamas (novak-7)**
```
Don't know if this is a wish or a bug, but can cause a totally scre**d up
board:

1) create a netlist,
2) then make modifications to schematic
3) update PCB by F8 Update PCB from schematic
4) (forget re-create netlist)
5) Read netlist in pcbnew

This re-loads state before 2)  It causes a mixed mess depending on Netlist
import options (keep/delete/change differeent objects) setting.

Solutions:

F8 Update PCB from schematic should re-create netlist (automatically or by
showing a warning to do so)

If inconsitency detected between the time of last F8 and the time of
netlist file a warning should be displayed.  They should be compared at
- loading the kicad_pcb
- importing netlist
- F8 update

Or F8 Update should simply work as a
1) (re-)create netlist
2) read netlist into pcbnew
sequence.  Still can't see what happens to keep/change options when F8
update...Read netlist is "smarter".
```

title: KiCad PCB fails thermals on complex pad stacks (lp:#1605049)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1605049) created by **PCB Wiz (1-pcb-wiz)**
```
Bug: For simple PADS stacks KiCad creates Thermals all ok, BUT if I define
DIFFERENT Stacks aka sizes/shapes on F.Cu from B.Cu, like this

(pad 1 thru_hole rect (at 0 0) (size 1.7272 1.7272) (drill 1.016) (layers
F.Cu F.Mask)
  (net 7 GND))
(pad 1 smd roundrect (at 0 0 22) (size 1.6 1.6) (layers B.Cu B.Mask)
(roundrect_rratio 0.1)
  (net 7 GND))

Such stacks are common when allowing more channel space on non-solder side,
and also with translation from other CAD tools.

Then, the first (mounted side) Stack thermally connects OK, however second
stack tries, but comes up short.

If I ask for Solid (no thermal), it also gets confused on the more complex
Pad Stack, & gives a round cutout for a rounded rect pad on non-mounted
side ?!.

Also, that variable Stack gives a false/unwanted DRC report, like

ErrType(25): Hole near pad
    @ (179.070 mm,104.140 mm): Pad 1 on F.Cu, Non-copper of J2
    @ (179.070 mm,104.140 mm): Pad 1 on B.Cu, Non-copper of J2

To me it is preferable to have _one_ stack define the Drill/Slot+Top, as
that is easier to edit later.

That means the DRC should tolerate a hole/Slot thought a SMD pad of the
SAME Part.PinNum


Tested using

title: DRC unable to be performed via Python scripting API (lp:#1600081)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1600081) created by **mithro (mithro)**
```
I posted the following to the KiCad Developer's mailing list and nobody
seems to be able to answer the question.

------------------------
I'm trying to figure out how to run the DRC in pcbnew from the Python
Scripting API. I've managed to get API into an iPython session
(https://github.com/mithro/kicad-length-matching-
checks/blob/master/ipython.py) to have a poke around but wasn't able to
find the right function to call.

It looks like if I can get the DRC to run, there seems to be an API for
accessing the marker's it adds to the board which exposes
https://github.com/KiCad/kicad-source-
mirror/blob/master/pcbnew/class_marker_pcb.h

GetMARKER(self, *args) method of pcbnew.BOARD instance
    GetMARKER(BOARD self, int index) -> MARKER_PCB

GetMARKERCount(self) method of pcbnew.BOARD instance
    GetMARKERCount(BOARD self) -> int

I did find, board.Test_Drc_Areas_Outlines_To_Areas_Outlines - but couldn't
figure out how to call it, or if it did what I wanted.

Test_Drc_Areas_Outlines_To_Areas_Outlines(self, *args) method of
pcbnew.BOARD instance
    Test_Drc_Areas_Outlines_To_Areas_Outlines(BOARD self, ZONE_CONTAINER
aArea_To_Examine, bool aCreate_Markers) -> int

There also seems to be the pcbnew.DRC_VISIBLE constant, but I couldn't find
where that might be used.

I had a dig around the KiCad source in the scripting directory, and the
other files with DRC in their name but didn't see anything similar mapped
into the API (but maybe I'm looking in the wrong area?)

Does anyone know how to cause the DRC to run from the Python scripting API?
(Or if it isn't currently exposed, the correct functions to expose via
SWIG?)

Thanks for your help!
------------------------

After more digging I've come to the conclusion it is currently impossible
to cause a DRC to run via the Python API. It would be awesome if this could
be added.
```

title: Improvement needed in XY and Snap for DXF to Footprint (lp:#1597949)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1597949) created by **PCB Wiz (1-pcb-wiz)**
```
Less an explicit 'bug', and more a klunky series of blindspots.

Improvement is needed in XY and Snap to make DXF to Footprint easier and
faster.

If you look at LibreCAD, that has a nice smarter Grid SNAP.
Viz: As you zoom in, and near any entity point LibreCAD can snap to both
Grid _and_ those points.
Simple, intuitive, and makes placing off-grid terminals on strange
footprints, literally a snap.
It becomes DXF in, Place Terminal, [Zoom-snap-release-repeat].


Using other CAD tools, they have a mouse option to SetOrigin to a selected
point.
Useful where you have a cluster on common-grid pins, but not on the
component origin.

Sometimes users need to manually clone XY, and you can now select.copy X,
then Select.paste X, then Select.Copy Y then Select.paste Y, but that is
tedious.
Suggestion: A means to copy/paste XY from the clipboard as comma separate
numbers, would be great.
Slashes steps to Select.CopyXY, Select.PasteXY
```

title: DXF import messes up some files (some objects scaled differently) (lp:#1594607)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1594607) created by **PCB Wiz (1-pcb-wiz)**
```
Importing 3 different CAD Saves of the _same_ original DXF, gives 3
differing outcomes in DXF import.

DXF loaded and saved by Double CAD imports ok, with Arcs, Circles and Text.

DXF flat export from PADS loads, but drops the Circle and Arcs

DXF full export from PADS, loads, but more mangled - looks to lose origin
info, as well as Circles and Arcs.

DXF load/save from A9CAD seems to scale wrong - DXF import may need a scale
choice added, as I think not all DXF files have explicit units included  ?
millimeters is a a global standard, but inch and mils are also common in
PCB design areas.

LibreCAD I tested, but it has a bug in release 2.1.0 that prevents full DXF
testing.
```

```
I believe that this may have been due to to the fact that I had several
legacy footprints assigned to parts in Eeschema and CvPcb prompted to try
to convert the footprints over but somehow my existing data was deleted and
I had to go back through and associate everything again.

opening it got the prompt to switch legacy footprints that were already
associated in Eeschema. 2) I saved CvPcb several times and even exited and
re-entered it and all the data was still there. 3) Computer froze so I
restarted it. 4) Opened CvPcb and was prompted to switch the legacy
footprints again. 5) I selected no (I believe) and all of the data was
gone.

title: 3D model path aliases improvement (lp:#1585341)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1585341) created by **Patrik Bachan (xorly)**
```
My KiCAD build version is 6816.
There were some changes in 3D path configuration recently. Now you have to
go through some FootPrint's 3D settings to Configure Paths and set aliases.
Good idea! When you set only 1 alias, you don't even have to modify 3D
model's name.
But when you want more...

1.
If you set more than 1 alias, you have to specify alias in 3D model's name.
Like global:library.3dshapes/model.wrl or local:model.wrl otherwise you
can't see model.
This could be improved by searching all paths if alias is not specified in
model name. You can already modify order of records, like it was intended
to work this way, to order them by priority.
If this will be done, final path should be displayed somewhere.

2.
Kicad shows warning every time it looks for 3D models and some path does
not exist.
It sounds ok until you set project specific path like ${KIPRJMOD}/3D, you
get this warning in each project that does not have such sub-directory.
This could be solved by project only 3D aliases and/or by silently ignoring
invalid paths and just hilighting them in window where you administrate
them.

Q.
Is this 3D path alias administration accessible simply from some menu or
just from footprint's 3D model config window?

What do you think about it?
```

title: Eeschema User Manual description of "Template Field Names" (now "Default Fields") should be improved (lp:#1575100)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1575100) created by **Robin Whittle (rw-p)**
```
The Eeschema User Manual has a brief, uninformative and I think incorrect
explanation of the Eeschema preference items "Template Field Names" as they
are known in 4.0.2-stable.  In the latest nightly (2016-04-23 BZR 6710, Git
c1f0ab9) this is known as "Default Fields", which I think is a better name.

The current description is:

     "You can define custom fields that will exist by default in each
component (even if left empty)."

This is an inadequate description of a very useful function, and it is
incorrect in that these fields do not exist in the schematic components or
their representation in schematic libraries.  They are presented as fields
in the edit dialogues but they are only written to the component in the
schematic or library if "OK" is chosen to close the edit dialogue.

I explored the behavior of this system with 4.0.2-stable at:
http://www.firstpr.com.au/kicad/#tfn .  I assume the behavior is the same
in the latest nightly.  The latest nightly has a new and improved user
interface which avoids confusion due to text boxes and an "Add" button,
which I think is the cause of a bug report
https://bugs.launchpad.net/kicad/+bug/1389272 which I think could now be
marked as resolved.

I suspect that the new user interface does not require any explanation.
Here is some suggested text to replace the current single sentence.
Ideally someone would check the validity of this and revise it to fit the
style of the manual.

- - -

Default Fields are a mechanism for easily introducing additional fields
into components in schematics or component definitions in schematic
libraries.

Each Default Field consists of a field name, a default value for this field
- which can be empty - and a flag which controls whether the value of this
field will be visible in the schematic editing screen and the printed
schematic.

These configuration items are part of the Eeschema configuration and are
not part of any schematic sheet or project.

The one or more Default Fields specified here do not exist in any
components in schematics or in  schematic libraries until each such
component is edited and the "OK" button is pressed in the edit dialogue
box.  Then, the one or more Default Fields are added to the already
existing fields for this component, starting at field 4, with any
previously existing fields 4 and above being renumbered accordingly.
Changes can be made to the value and/or visibility flag during this initial
edit session or at any subsequent time.

Later changes to the default value of a Default Field will not affect the
value of fields which have already been added to components.  Once one or
more fields have been added to a component, each also has parameters for
position, size and orientation of the text, when displayed in the
schematic.

- - -

The ability to add one or more new fields into components, per component or
at the library level, is powerful and important.  It is the basis for
several attempts at creating greatly improved BOMs and the like, such as
those described at: https://rheingoldheavy.com/category/education/kicad/  .

I think the explanation could be enhanced at the start or end by some
mention of the use of these fields in creating sophisticated schematic-
based data systems as the basis for generating BOMs.
```

title: proportionally shrinking conflicting zones (lp:#1571926)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1571926) created by **Simon Richter (sjr)**
```
When two zones intersect, the zone with lower priority is shrunk to avoid a
conflict.

It would be great to have a way to have both zones shrink proportionally,
so e.g. if 1:1 is specified, the boundary for the higher-priority zone will
go exactly down the middle of the clearance.

2:1 means that the zone specifying 2 will shrink 2/3 of the clearance.

0:1 means that the zone specifying 0 will not yield, even if it is lower-
priority.

0:0 means traditional behaviour -- higher-priority zone wins.
```

title: Zone vs. Soldermask clearance collisions at corners (lp:#1563744)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1563744) created by **Paul "LeoNerd" Evans (leonerd)**
```
If you place an SMT pad in a zone, due to the way the zone clearance gets
rounded corners it can mean there's a little bit of copper that overlaps
into the pad area.

For example: the attached screenshot shows a zone of clearance 0.01in
inside which is placed an SMT pad of mask clearance just under 0.008in (the
actual value 0.007874015748in being 0.2mm). You would expect that this is
perfectly safe; a nice 0.002in of safety margin between the solder mask
opening and the copper zone.

But you'd be wrong. The problem is that the zone clearance only applies
vertically and horizontally from the pad; the cleared area within the zone
gets a rounded corner of radius 0.010in, meaning it could only guarantee
clearance of a square corner at most 0.00707...in (0.01in * sqrt(2)) wide.
The mask clearance of 0.008in gives a tiny margin of bare copper from the
filled zone exposed within the pad clearance area.

This isn't just a rendering issue; I have had a bad copper run of boards
from the fab because of actual spilled out copper in these pad areas,
causing grounding shorts to the pads when soldered.

As a workaround for these collisions I've been manually editing the per-pad
Cu clearance settings and increasing it on any pad that would be affected.
I'd prefer to leave the global zone clearance at a nice small 0.01in though
because I need to route some grounding pour between TTH connector pads, so
that can't be too big.
```

description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1562672) created by **Joan (joanthesparky)**
```
I currently switched from BZR5978 to BZR6608 on Windows 64bit.

In BZR5978 it was possible to open independent 3D views from PCBnew, the
footprint editor and the footprint browser.
One got a max of three separate windows that were independent of each other
(note *).

Fast forward to BZR6608 and that is no more.
When I open the 3D view from PCBnew and then try to open another one from
the footprint editor the focus jumps to the 3d view from PCBnew (window
goes in front of all else), but only shows the board, not the footprint I
wanted to see.
To show me the footprint I have to close the PCBnew 3D view and only then I
can open the 3D view for the footprint.

Related might be a bug that shows solder mask clearances for footprints in
the 3D view, although the clearances settings for the pads, the footprint
and the global board values in PCBnew are all at ZERO (note **).
This also didn't happen back in BZR5978.


*)
just tested it, by reinstalling the BZR5978 over BZR6608 - I can have three
independent 3D views - see screenshot.
The interesting part might be, that the 3D windows were located off-screen
- each one of them. I had to use this to get them pop back into existence:
http://superuser.com/questions/53585/how-to-move-windows-that-open-up-
offscreen

**)
if you think that's a separate bug I'll file another report, no problem.
I already have some info with a screenshot here:
https://forum.kicad.info/t/footprint-editor-non-zero-solder-mask-clearance-

title: The Footprint Editor replaces filesystem sym links (lp:#1548798)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1548798) created by **Hermann Kleier (hermann-kleier)**
```
I am using kicad 0.201602221446+6578~42~ubuntu15.10.1.

I maintain a local footprint archive. Here, “archive” is not a kind of
a compressed container. It is merely a directory structure with files
in it. To simplify matters, the directory is named ${KICAD}. The
project lives in the directory ${BOARD} with a sub-directory
${BOARD}/kicad/mod/connect_local.pretty “pointing” into the
archive. That way I keep track which footprints are REQUIRED by the
project and —the other way around— I can keep track of the utilization
of a particular component. “Pointing” is done by file system
links. This all works fine. But if I update a footprint the link is
destroyed by the footprint editor.

In detail:

 1  Initially there is no link between archive and project:

    h@b4:${BOARD}/kicad/mod/connect_local.pretty$ ls -l
SMA_EDGE_MNT.kicad_mod
    ls: cannot access SMA_EDGE_MNT.kicad_mod: No such file or directory

 2a “SMA_EDGE_MNT” is required, create a link:

    h@b4:${BOARD}/kicad/mod/connect_local.pretty$ ln -s
${KICAD}/mod/connect_local.pretty/SMA_EDGE_MNT.kicad_mod .
    h@b4:${BOARD}/kicad/mod/connect_local.pretty$ ls -l
SMA_EDGE_MNT.kicad_mod
    lrwxrwxrwx 1 h me 65 Feb 23 12:52 SMA_EDGE_MNT.kicad_mod ->
${KICAD}/mod/connect_local.pretty/SMA_EDGE_MNT.kicad_mod

 3a The footprint is accessible from the project now. But after
    updating the footprint we have:

    h@b4:${BOARD}/kicad/mod/connect_local.pretty$ ls -l
SMA_EDGE_MNT.kicad_mod
    -rw-r--r-- 1 h me 2694 Feb 23 12:52 SMA_EDGE_MNT.kicad_mod

    The link is replaced by an ordinary file. The changes are lost and
    will never be recorded in the archive.

 2b Instead of creating a symlink (which must be explicitly evaluated
    within the program) I use a hardlink to refer to the archive:

    h@b4:${BOARD}/kicad/mod/connect_local.pretty$ ln
${KICAD}/mod/connect_local.pretty/SMA_EDGE_MNT.kicad_mod .
    h@b4:${BOARD}/kicad/mod/connect_local.pretty$ ls -l
SMA_EDGE_MNT.kicad_mod
    -rw-r--r-- 2 h me 2694 Feb 23 12:52 SMA_EDGE_MNT.kicad_mod

 3b Again, the footprint can be read from the project. But after the
    first write we have:

    h@b4:${BOARD}/kicad/mod/connect_local.pretty$ ls -l
SMA_EDGE_MNT.kicad_mod
    -rw-r--r-- 1 h me 2690 Feb 23 12:55 SMA_EDGE_MNT.kicad_mod

    And gain, the link is broken (link count reset to 1).

This is nasty, because updates are lost “magically” and it took me
some time to find out where the various revisions of my footprint came
from. There is a workaround, though. Use the “Export footprint” button
and write directly into the archive. That way the relations between
components and projects are lost.
```

title: Licence violation for icons (lp:#1545350)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1545350) created by **Jonas Stein (news-g)**
```
The icons in bitmaps_png/sources are not properly included in kicad.

The CREDITS file mentions "License: GPL or equivalent"
but GPL requires to name the license and the authors.

Which GPL is meant here? GPL-2?

KiCad should give the honor to the creators who made the original icons,
and who contributed to them (derived work).

The collection of links does not help to find out who made which icon under
which license.
Some links are even just search engines or forum posts.

For example the license of Oxygen Icons (GNU LGPL 3) can be found here:
https://techbase.kde.org/Projects/Oxygen/Licensing

We do not want to steal from open source and want to give proper
attribution.
Furthermore this is important for distributions and package maintainers
too.

title: Default location for templates folder on Windows often not writeable (lp:#1543443)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1543443) created by **Dieter Kunkel (dieter-kunkel)**
```
From WIN7 and up there is a problem using <Program Files> for files that
get written too (e.g. modified). This path is partially virtually,
depending of the current user. Administrator right are required to write.

Microsoft designed the path c:\ProgramData for these things. Examples and
templates shall be installed there. Leave the original component libraries
and template backups (so these cannot be overwritten accidentially).

I think, a lot of the reported problems with 'cannot write' or disappeared
files depends on this.

Some of my jobs include writing software that is intended to run on
computers that get used by several user and all around the worl and with
any Windows version you can think of.
```

title: Trace length matching length detection logic is inconsistent with displayed length test. (lp:#1541070)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1541070) created by **Dick Hollenbeck (dickelbeck)**
```
pcbnew GAL:

The attached screenshot shows some nets that I would've liked to length
match as they travel to/from a board to board SMD connector on far right to
a chip on the far left.  In the middle is a male thru hole header whose
purpose is test point access for each of the nets.

The test point pads seem to bisect the nets into two lengths, pre- and
post- test pad runs.  All the nets are on the top layer, both post- and
pre- test pad portions.  If one temporarily changes all the test pads to
reside only on the back Cu layer, then clicking on any part of the net then
shows the full length of the net, extending from SMD connector to chip.
The test pads are temporarily set aside.   Or so one would think.

When I go to length match these nets, the length detection logic seems to
bring the test pads back in and reverts to the bisection.  So I am unable
to length match the nets, which at this moment, because of the temporary
change to my test pads,  technically consist of the full run from SMD to
chip.  The length matching test seems to use different code than the "click
on any segment of the net and update the status bar code".

Also, bug #2, during length matching drag, the changing length shown
numerically not updating with sufficient granularity, neither for a) mouse
movements, and b) nor for numeric meandering wave shaping using the number
keys.  b) is especially noticeable.
```

title: Launching footprint editor from PcbNew changes default units to mm (lp:#1538239)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1538239) created by **Art (diametrix)**
```
Seems to affect all canvases.  Suppose your main units that you work with
are inches and you have it selected in the preferences and you have one
footprint which dimensions are specified in mm.  Your normal work flow
would be go to Preferences in PcbNew -> change to mm -> Launch Edit
Footprint and then do actual editing.  When you do that, the units jump
back to whatever you had selected previously and you have to go back to
PCBNew and change them again.  For example - if you have inches selected,
you change it to mm in preferences.  You can see your units change to mm at
the bottom of the screen.  Now when you launch footprint editor the units
change back to inches (both in PcbNew and footprint editor) and you have to
change them second time around.

Just to mention something, it would be ideal if the units in footprint
editor would be independent from the units of the PcbNew for the reason
mentioned above.
```

title: Override pin type (lp:#1526213)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1526213) created by **Per Jakobsen (pdj)**
```
Example:
uC is measuring the current on the low-side of an H-bridge. The H-bridge is
connected to GND rail through a shunt resistor, and the uC is meauring
voltage across the resistor (single-ended A/D). Without any flags I get
"Pin connected to some other pins but no pin to drive it". Placing a flag
on the high-side of the shunt resistor removes this DRC-warning, but
introduces another one: "Conflict problem between pins" as the uC-pin is a
configurable I/O (bi-directional).

Changing the type of the uC pin is not a good option, removing the check is
not ideal, and allowing the warning is not good practice either.

It would be nice if one could override specific pins of a component, e.g. a
bi-directional pin could be overridden as pure input or pure output if the
specific schematic requires. This will remove the warnings, and also
provide information on how the uC should be hardware-configured in this
context.

I'm sure boards with FPGA's could benefit from this feature as well.
```

title: Using tilde inside labels may confuse ERC module in Eeschema (lp:#1522583)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1522583) created by **Kerusey Karyu (keruseykaryu-deactivatedaccount)**
```
Eeschema permits the use of tilde character (~) in labels to distinguish
inverted signals.
You can use both "~LABEL" and "~LABEL~" scheme which has the same visual
effect: the label become overscored.

Unfortunately for the ERC module these two labels are different which
results in an ERC error:
"ErrType (2): Pin not connected (and do not connect the symbol found on
this pin)"

I see two options, keeping current functionality:
 - Eeschema will automatically add the ending tilde, when will not find
another one in the string.
 - Eeschema will remove the final tilde if there are no more characters
following the tilde.

```
Creating new schematic library components can be a tedious task. It can be
a real pain to edit each pin one at a time in a part with many pins. I feel
like a lot of time could be saved here since all you are really doing is
copying information from the datasheet. It would be much better if the
spreadsheet-like pin table were editable. I am aware of the Quick KICAD
Library Component Builder at http://kicad.rohrbacher.net/quicklib.php . But
it would be much better if this functionality were built in.  Ideally this
feature would include some sort of text parsing utility so that the
information could, as much so as possible, just be cut and pasted from the
table in the datasheet.
```

title: Text wrapping in eeschema (lp:#1490050)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1490050) created by **Blair Bonnett (bcb)**
```
When redesigning the eeschema file format, would it be possible to add text
wrapping support for text blocks in eeschema? Either as an option to the
standard text item, or as a separate wrapped text object. Let the user
specify the width and alignment of the lines (left-, center-, or right-
aligned, or justified) and have eeschema break and space the lines to suit.

Paragraph behaviour would also need to be specified; maybe a single newline
(\r, \n, \r\n or whatever based on platform) is ignored, and two or more
consecutive are treated as a new paragraph?

As an example, in my latest design I have a three-paragraph novel
describing the buck converter, how various component values were
calculated, and current requirements for the inductor. It would be nice to
be able to just specify a width rather than have to wrap it manually.
```
